wikipedia_page.main: Paul Seaward is a British historian specialising in seventeenth-century English history.He is a Director of The History of Parliament Trust. With Martin Dzelzainis, he is General Editor of the Oxford edition of the works of Lord Clarendon.

response: *Paul Seaward: (1988) A Restoration Publicist:James Howell and the Earl of Clarendon, 1661-6
*1265-2015 ed. Paul Seaward, The Story of Parliament: Celebrating 750 Years of Parliament in Britain (History of Parliament Trust, London, 2015).
*Ruth Paley and Paul Seaward, eds., Honour, Interest & Power: An Illustrated History of the House of Lords, 1660–1715 (Boydell & Brewer, London, 2010)

Thomas Crewe was again elected as Speaker of the House of Commons, having served in that office previously, but this led Sir John Eliot to refer to the position as "frequently filled by nullities, men selected for mere Court convenience".Paul Seaward, Speakers and the Speakership: Presiding Officers and the Management of Business from the Middle Ages to the Twenty-first Century (2010), p. 90 online at books.google.com
*Paul Seaward (ed.), Edward Hyde, Earl of Clarendon: The History of the Rebellion. A New Selection (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2009).
*(editor, with Tim Harris and Paul Seaward), The Politics of Religion in Restoration England (Oxford: Blackwell, 1990).
